comments.html:
- FWSM will always be IPv6 in software - a new device that yet has to be released will replace FWSM and do IPv6 in hw (supposedly).
- You can throw away your ACE10's & ACE20's because they will never do IPv6
- WLC does not do IPv6
comments.name: Job Snijders

comments.html:
FWSM is doing IPv6 on NP3 not in CPU.
ASA IPv6 bugs and features ... don't get me started, it's still a long way to go :-)
comments.name: Isam

comments.html: @Isam, thanks, I did not know that. Anyway: FWSM will pass through no more than 60 to 80 mbit of traffic, which makes it relatively useless in Service Provider context.
comments.name: Job Snijders

comments.html: Thanks for the update, @Isam. Was that true a year ago as well? In that case, I will update the second column of the table and the last year's post.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Up through at least 15.0(1)M and 12.2(53)SE2 the IPv6 support for management protocols is spotty; syslog is there, SNMP traps and the RADIUS/TACACS control plane aren't. I haven't checked the very latest images, though.
comments.name: JS

comments.html: @Ivan the NP3 is also called "the slow path" here http://www.scribd.com/doc/28698783/FWSM-Architecture
comments.name: Job Snijders

comments.html:
IMO ASAs are not even close to being IPv6 ready.

As of 8.2 code all it really does is basic unicast routing. ASA 8.3 code added a few things (like IPv6 LAN to LAN IPsec). It doesn't change the fact that there is "poor" feature parity between IPv4 and IPv6. In this case, "poor" is a severe understatement.

IPv6 IPsec? Static LAN to LAN only.
IPv6 remote access VPN - L2TP, AnyConnect? nope.
dynamic routing - OSPFv3 or RIPng? nope

PIXes and ASAs support all of the above for IPv4 networks.

IOS boxes don't have feature parity either but they are MUCH MUCH farther along, especially if you are really brave and run 15.1T ;)
comments.name: Phil

comments.html: Whoever told you that FWSM only does 60-80mbit of throughput was pulling your leg.
comments.name: chris

comments.html: Chris, we're talking about IPv6 here. Can FWSM do more with IPv6 traffic? Do you have any hard performance data? I would love to publish it.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
@Ivan, I believe it was always the case. Theoretical performance will be at around 500Mbit/s due to architecture limitation - check Job's link below. Real performance will vary ;-)

In other words forget about FWSM and IPv6, although if you have a big account behind you, contact your Cisco SE, maybe they can talk some sense into development. For everyone else, we have to wait for the next-generation-firewall-in-chassis - people from Cisco told me it's not that long of a wait (no specifics).
comments.name: Isam

comments.html:
I'm far from being an expert on the FWSM, so I have to rely on external sources. The BRKSEC-3020 (Advanced Firewalls) section from Cisco Live 2010 claims on Slide #25 that FWSM does IPv6 in the control point central CPU, not in the NP slow path (NP3).

If anyone has anything more authoritative pointing to a different conclusion (IPv6 running on NP3), please share it.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
According to this discussion
http://www.gossamer-threads.com/lists/cisco/nsp/132935?do=post_view_threaded#132935
and reply from cisco, IPv6 is handled by CPU - PIII.
comments.name: Martin Zidek

comments.html: Funny seeing this as I learnt just this week that CCP won't even know about ipv6 until may 2011.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: I'll try to arrange for some performance tests with the FWSM's i have access to. That should solve the matter of throughput. :-)
comments.name: Job Snijders

comments.html: I have that Chambers video mentally bookmarked, ready to use in any TAC case if an engineer gives me a hard time in regards to IPv6. =)
comments.name: Frank Bulk

comments.html: Any idea how a VPN client is supposed to recieve an IPv6 DNS server when using the AnyConnect client?
comments.name: Frank Bulk

comments.html: Currently the only way for a client to receive DNS information is to issue a DHCPv6 request, which means that the router has to set the other-config flag in RA messages.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
Ivan, indeed I stand corrected, a few chats with guys in TAC and indeed FWSM does everything IPv6.
On top you might find this interesting:
http://tools.cisco.com/Support/BugToolKit/search/getBugDetails.do?method=fetchBugDetails&bugId=CSCtl77322

comments.html: I seem to be running into an issue where the FWSM doesn't route more then 500-550 Mbit of traffic.  Can someone provide more detail about the resource limitations mentioned above.  I looked at the slides but don't see where it specifically talks about that limitation, I see the PPS limit that drops throughput to the 2 gbit range.
